But when I try to export PDF reports that use these DLLs via the API Gateway, I only get (---) as a response instead of base 64.  I assume this is because an internal error is generated because that DLL is not included in the API gateway installation on Linux.

Is there a way to apply that DLL to the API Gateway so that the report can be generated correctly?

entry.title: SuccessFactors Recruiting: Enhancement Request for Multiple Document Uploads in Interview Central
entry.content:
Hello HCM Community!

I wanted to share an SAP Influence enhancement request related to SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting ‚Äì Interview Central and see if others across HCM teams are running into the same challenge.

At the moment, Interview Central only allows one document to be uploaded under Upload Interview Notes. There‚Äôs no ability to multi-select files or upload additional documents once a note is added. For organizations using structured interview forms, panel interviews, or multiple interviewer feedback documents, this creates extra administrative work and inconsistent record-keeping.

We‚Äôve submitted an enhancement request asking SAP to support multiple document uploads within Interview Central, similar to other attachment areas across SuccessFactors.

If this limitation affects your recruiting, HRIS, or talent teams, I‚Äôd really appreciate your vote and/or comment on the request:
Improvement Request | Enable Multiple Document Uploads in Interview Central ‚Äì Interview Notes 

Additional customer support and use cases help give this request more visibility with the product team. Thanks in advance, and happy to connect with others who are navigating the same workaround today.

entry.title: No Data Returned in CDS I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost After Filling Parameters (Production Order Cos
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I hope you are doing well.

I am currently working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, and I am trying to build a production cost analysis in Power BI using CDS views as the data source.

My objective is to analyze production order costs by activity, such as:

  • Labor hours (man-hours)

  • Machine hours

  • Utility-related costs (energy, water, etc.)

  • Actual vs planned/target costs associated with manufacturing or process orders

The goal is to extract this information via a CDS view and consume it in Power BI.

At the moment, I am using the CDS view:

  • I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost

When I try to preview this CDS, the system requires the following parameters:

  • Ledger

  • Fiscal Year Period From

  • Fiscal Year Period To

  • Currency Role

Even after entering valid values for all these parameters, no data is returned in the preview.

Because of this behavior, I am not sure whether:

  • This CDS requires additional CO configuration (e.g. settlement, period-end closing, or cost posting prerequisites),

  • The parameters (ledger, fiscal year/period, or currency role) must be provided in a specific way,

  • Or if this CDS is not intended to be consumed directly for detailed production order cost analysis.

My questions are:

  1. Has anyone successfully used I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost and faced a similar issue with no data returned?

  2. Are there any known prerequisites (e.g. cost postings, activity confirmations, period-end processes) required for this CDS to return data?

  3. Are there alternative CDS views recommended to analyze costs associated with production or process orders, especially with a breakdown by activities (labor, machine) and cost components?

Any guidance, experience, or best practices would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you very much in advance for your support.

Best regards,
Sergio

entry.title: Re: Intra Company Stock transport order with Advanced shipping and receiving (ASR) in SAP S/4HANA 20
entry.content:
Hello everyone, thank you for this very helpful post!

We are currently working with Intra-Company Stock Transport Orders (STO) in combination with Advanced Shipping and Receiving (ASR) and EWM, and I would like to clarify a few points after upgrading our system to SAP S/4HANA 2025.

1. STO between two EWM-managed storage locations ‚Äì error at the final step

We are creating an Intra-Company STO between two EWM-managed storage locations.
The process runs correctly through most steps; however, at the final execution step (delivery update / goods issue / EWM processing), the process fails with an error and cannot be completed.

"Error in updating delivery 18000**** from TM

Message No. LESHP_TM_INT054

Diagnosis

An error occurred in the updating of delivery 18000**** using the function module WS_DELIVERY_UPDATE_2, which was triggered by Transportation Management."

Important context:

  • the system has already been upgraded to SAP S/4HANA 2025

  • the issue still occurs after the upgrade

    Could you please advise:

    • what are the standard limitations or prerequisites for completing the final STO step in an EWM‚ÄìEWM scenario with ASR?

    • are there any specific configuration requirements, event sequences, or integration constraints in SAP S/4HANA 2025 that could explain this behavior?

      2. STO process between non-EWM and EWM storage locations

      Is there an official SAP documentation or recommended process description for STO scenarios where only one side is EWM-managed, for example:

      • non-EWM ‚Üí EWM

      • EWM ‚Üí non-EWM

        In particular:

        • are these mixed scenarios fully supported in SAP S/4HANA 2025?

        • how does the delivery creation, goods issue/receipt, and ASR integration differ compared to a pure EWM‚ÄìEWM scenario?

          We are trying to clearly understand which STO + ASR patterns are supported in SAP S/4HANA 2025, and which scenarios may still require alternative process designs.

          Thank you in advance for your guidance and experience sharing!

first check if your role has the proper authorization

this is what sap is checking

define role I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost {

grant

select

on

I_MfgOrderActlPlanTgtLdgrCost

where ( OrderCategory, OrderType, Plant ) ?= aspect pfcg_auth ( C_AFKO_AWA, AUTYP, AUFART, WERKS, ACTVT = '03' )

and ( CompanyCode ) ?= aspect pfcg_auth( F_BKPF_BUK, BUKRS, ACTVT = '03' )

and ( OrderType ) ?= aspect pfcg_auth( K_ORDER, AUFART, CO_ACTION = '3028' );

}

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud compass in Q1 2026 - New Use Cases, Enhanced Workflow
entry.content:
2026 is going to be an exciting year for compass! For fans of Monte Carlo Simulation and scenario modelling in SAP Analytics Cloud, we shall kick the year off with three highly requested enhancements for Q1:

  1. Supporting AVG excl. NULL and AVG incl. unbooked for drivers
  2. Enabling simulation from dashboards with complex filters
  3. Enabling changing of target settings after simulation creation

Let me walk you through them:

 

AVG excl. NULL and AVG incl. unbooked for drivers

Previously, users were only able to model the uncertainty of key drivers with SUM aggregation or SUM exception aggregation. Even though this applies for most key drivers, users wishing to simulate with averages were left out of the game. The new support of AVG excl. NULL and AVG incl. unbooked for drivers will open the door now to simulations with average prices, average discount, average hours or any KPI which should not be summed up to reflect accurate performance assessment. This means that simulation for use cases such sales promotions or energy expenses etc. are now possible.  
(If you are unsure about the differences between the different AVG variants, check out this great blog from Alecsandra Dimofte.)


Before the enhancement, key drivers modelled with AVG excl. NULL or incl. unbooked will be blocked from simulation. 


Now users will be able to model uncertainties for key drivers modelled with AVG excl. NULL or incl. unbooked.

 

Enabling simulation from dashboards with complex filters

In the past, complex filters applied on the story, page or table level would block the creation of compass simulations directly from the story table. These complex filters include:

  • Attribute
  • Range
  • Exclude
  • Advanced filter

With the latest enhancement, the restriction is lifted and users could directly create a compass simulation right off the dashboard even with this setup. Dashboard creators, especially those dependent on time range filters or exclude filter for ease of selection, will benefit from the flexibility this feature brings to their story design to provide end users with a direct trigger for compass simulation. Take note that the complex filters applied will be displayed as read-only in compass though. Users are free to simulate right away in compass or to substitute the complex filters with something simpler before proceeding, if preferred.

Range filters and other complex filters will no longer block the direct trigger of a compass simulation from a story table. 

 

Enabling changing of target settings after simulation creation

Before Q1 2026, it was not possible to make adjustments to a compass simulation target setting once a scenario has been created. Any changes to the target setting after simulation creation would require manual removal of existing scenarios, as it would be a change in the simulation calculation. 
With the latest enhancement, the workflow has become more flexible. Users can change the target settings at any point in time. After applying the changes, the prior simulation results of private scenarios will be discarded (as the prior calculation will differ from that of the current target settings), but the driver value configurations will be retained. Users seeking to simulate impact on another similar target KPI will benefit from the ability to continue right away without having to set up identical assumptions for common drivers again.
Public scenarios, on the other hand, will be marked as invalid, but both results and driver value configurations will be retained, in case there is a need to archive past simulations despite the difference in target settings. 

 

Simulation target settings can be changed now even after scenario creation. Driver value configurations will be retained in the private scenarios.

 

With these three new enhancements in Q1 2026, compass users will experience more flexibility in handling, with better re-use of assumption modelling efforts, and more variety in the spectrum of possible drivers.

As usual, we are always on the look out for areas where compass could be sharpened even further. Have an opinion here? Do tell us what you think in the influence portal! In fact, our first feature in Q1 2026 was inspired by the a topic raised by @David_Nicolay_ . Thank you and do keep them coming!

entry.title: The Future of Data in Procurement with Stacy Yoeckel
entry.content:
Unlocking the Future of Procurement: Why Data Quality‚Äîand Human Alignment‚ÄîMatter More Than Ever

In a recent episode of The Future of Procurement Podcast, host Erik Derenne and guest Stacy Yoeckel, Founder and Chief Data & AI Strategist at Modern Data Compass, unpacked one of the most misunderstood yet mission‚Äëcritical topics in business today: data. Their conversation revealed an essential truth‚ÄîAI may be the accelerant, but data is the fuel, and organizations can‚Äôt afford for that fuel to be contaminated. üöÄ

From demystifying data roles to exposing the challenges of poor data hygiene, this episode is a masterclass for procurement professionals seeking to elevate their impact in an AI‚Äëpowered world.

 

Why Data Roles Matter‚ÄîAnd Why They‚Äôre Often Misunderstood üß©

Stacy breaks down the ecosystem of modern data work into a simple flow:

  • Data engineers/architects bring data together, clean it, and model it for use.
  • Data analysts translate that data into meaningful business insights.
  • Data scientists push those insights further‚Äîpredicting outcomes and identifying new opportunities.

Each role depends on the other. And the reason organizations struggle? They often skip ahead, saying ‚ÄúWe need a data scientist!‚Äù before understanding whether they even have clean, reliable data for one to use. Stacy‚Äôs point is clear: You can‚Äôt build predictive magic on top of chaotic inputs.

 

Modeling and Context: The Hidden Work Behind Every Insight üèóÔ∏è

A standout takeaway is the importance of data modeling with business context. Modeling isn‚Äôt just putting data in a table; it‚Äôs translating business rules‚Äîlike categories, cost centers, supplier logic‚Äîinto a structured system that enables accurate reporting and AI training.

Without it? You get garbage in, garbage out. Or worse‚Äîyou get insights that look trustworthy but aren‚Äôt. ü§Ø

Stacy emphasizes that building this foundation takes time, patience, and alignment. Leaders often underestimate the complexity behind ‚Äújust adding one more field‚Äù or ‚Äúpulling one more report.‚Äù In reality, accuracy requires meticulous validation and ongoing testing.

 

AI Is Changing the Game‚ÄîBut Only for Organizations With the Right Foundation ü§ñ‚ú®

While AI‚Äôs promise is enormous, Stacy is quick to underscore a critical message: AI is only as good as the data you feed it.

The real shift isn‚Äôt about replacing data scientists; it‚Äôs about democratizing insights. AI can now surface answers in seconds that used to take analysts days‚Äîbut only if those algorithms have access to robust, enriched, well‚Äëgoverned data.

The future of procurement will rely heavily on:

  • Broader datasets, not narrow slices
  • Semantic layers that embed business intelligence directly into AI logic
  • Governance models that ensure accuracy, privacy, and trust

When done right, procurement teams will gain instant clarity on spend patterns, supplier performance, risks, and opportunities‚Äîmoving from reactive to predictive decision-making.

 

Culture and Process: The Missing Links in Data Transformation üå±

One of Stacy‚Äôs most practical insights is that technology alone can‚Äôt fix process or culture problems.

Organizations often deploy new tools yet keep outdated processes‚Äîor fail to educate frontline stakeholders on the importance of accurate data entry. The result? Misaligned KPIs, inconsistent definitions, and system‚Äëgenerated outputs nobody trusts.

Successful companies, Stacy notes, create:

  • Clear data ownership
  • Cross‚Äëfunctional alignment
  • Transparency around strategy
  • Continuous evolution of configuration and process

This keeps data trustworthy‚Äînot just the reports built on top of it.

 

Procurement‚Äôs Role: Be the Bridge, Not the Bottleneck üîó

Procurement professionals often underestimate their influence on data quality and strategy. Stacy argues they can (and should) play a powerful role by:

  • Using analytics to guide stakeholders
  • Helping define what data should be captured upstream
  • Collaborating across teams to enrich supplier information
  • Leveraging external data‚Äîmarket shifts, tariffs, industry benchmarks‚Äîalongside internal metrics

The combination of data, context, and supplier relationships is where procurement can differentiate itself as a strategic powerhouse.

 

A Glimpse into the Future: Real‚ÄëTime, Insight‚ÄëDriven Procurement üîÆ

Stacy‚Äôs prediction for what‚Äôs next is bold but realistic: real‚Äëtime procurement insights powered by strong data foundations and AI augmentation.

Category managers will soon ask questions directly to AI-powered agents and get immediate, context‚Äëaware guidance. Negotiations will be sharper, sourcing cycles faster, and opportunity identification more proactive than ever before.

But only for the companies doing the groundwork today.

 

Final Thoughts: Better Data, Better Decisions, Better Outcomes üìà

The episode leaves listeners with one fundamental truth: good insights come from good data, and bad data leads to‚Ä¶ meetings. Lots of them.

As procurement and AI continue to converge, organizations that invest in data modeling, governance, and stakeholder alignment will unlock speed, accuracy, and competitive advantage. Those that don‚Äôt? They‚Äôll remain stuck in manual work, inconsistent reporting, and missed opportunities.

Stacy‚Äôs advice is clear‚Äîstart with the foundation, build alignment, and embrace AI when your organization is ready.

If you‚Äôre exploring how to elevate your procurement data strategy, this conversation is a must‚Äëlisten‚Äîand a reminder that the future of procurement begins with the quality of the data you trust today.

Tool Overview

entry.title: Re: RAP Fiori Elements List Report Page with Analytical T...
entry.content:
@DanielSchneider

Regarding your first question, list reports are not only for edit scenarios, but for analytical scenarios as well. List Report page supports three table types: Responsive, Grid, and Analytical. Analytical table is not for transactional scenarios, because each row does not represent a single entity which is editable. and navigating from an aggregated row to a object page would not be possible.

Regarding your second question (why @odata.applySupportedForAggregation is not allowed), I guess that's because you put the annotation on the root view entity which is for transactional RAP BO.

entry.title: Re: SAC Data Action: DELETE() with IF condition not working

Hi @Amir

Please test the script "IF [d/DIMENSION_MATERIAL] == [d/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY].[p/Material] THEN".

In addition, please check the property value of the "[d/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY].[p/Material]". Suppose the property value is Null; a null value is not considered in comparisons and is therefore excluded from the scope. So, if a property is Null, please add a dummy member (e.g., "#") as the property value.

Regards,

Moonjun

entry.title: Backflush program based on Plant & Order with Sequential Sorting per Order- New Feature S4H 2023
entry.content:
New Functionality-From Release S4CORE 108( can be downported to lower version), SAP has enhanced the CORUPROC( Backflush Program) and has added below fields to execute the Program based on actual business needs.

  • AUFNR( Order Number)
  • WERKS( Plant)
  • Sort Order by Order Number 

Business requirement-  For our customer,  We had built a custom Fiori App which is based on synchronous GR and GI posting on Process Orders confirmation. Since the consumption, GR and confirmation are triggered by  BAPI_PROCORDCONF_CREATE_TT and APIs in our custom app, the immediate GR and GI sometime end up in locking issue.  

To handle locking issue for immediate GR/ Backflush/ Confirmation, SAP generally recommends to decouple the GR and GI process if these are handled via BAPI/APIs.

In this case, SAP has given Option to Post GR( real time) and Consumption( In background) to avoid locking issue. Also SAP suggest to run ‚ÄòCORUPROC‚Äô program in background to park confirmation and trigger ‚ÄòBACKFLUSH‚Äô via Job. GR and confirmation are handled in real time via below config & Backflush via job( SE38 CORUPROC)

Earlier CORUPROC program has no AUFNR & WERKS field which can be executed per Plant and consume order Sequentially based on Component staging.

With a modification note( 1008686 - CORUPROC: Selection by order and plant),  its now possible  to use the order number and plant as additional selection criteria. Also a new  parameter P_SORT (Sorting by Order Number only for S4HANA 2023). If the parameter is set, the goods movements are sorted by order number in advance. This Sorting parameter of in CORUPROC always consume order based on staging of Raw materials which is better aligned to customer backflush/consumption strategy. This parameter also improves the performance if storage locations are EWM-relevant and  production material requests are used during staging.

To use this functionality, the confirmation parameter is adjusted to immediate facilitate GR and confirmation. However, the backflush of components to be posted via Background job( CORUPROC)

Post note implementation( Its a modification Note), it introduces additional fields and sorting parameter

Scheduled the job of the CORUPROC program 

  The job is scheduled to consume in every 2 minutes Per Plant and Per Order

Created 3 Order( PMR based Cross Order) and confirmation is posted 

1000642, 1000643 and  1000644.

Sequentially posted the confirmation of 3 Orders and CORUPROC job( Per Plant/ Order) was scheduled.

The CORUPROC job was executed and consumed the Order components sequentially

time stamp of backflush sequentially.

PMR updation.

Thanks for reading. All tests are performed in S4 HANA 2025 FPS00 version.

Reference-  

  • 1008686 - CORUPROC: Selection by order and plant
  • 208477 - Consulting: Process control in confirmation

This functionality will only work on Embedded EWM. Never use backflush from S4 if its Decentralized on S4H. Customer should always built a custom program or logic using /SCWM/MFG_CONSUME_ITEMS_EXT if its decentral EWM.

entry.title: Resolving Nested WDA Application Navigation Issues in SAP Build Work Zone
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

We are currently migrating our Enterprise Portal to SAP BTP ‚Äì Build Work Zone (Standard Edition). During this migration, we encountered a few challenges. One of the key issues‚Äîand its resolution‚Äîis described in this blog to help others facing a similar situation.

Please note we created Local Artifact in the Work Zone and connected the S/4HANA system through Cloud Connector Tunnled access.

 

Issue Description

We have several ESS Web Dynpro ABAP (WDA) applications running on the S/4HANA system that need to be accessed through SAP Build Work Zone.

After completing all the required configurations, we encountered an error while accessing nested WDA applications through Work Zone.

What do we mean by ‚ÄúNested WDA‚Äù?

For example, we have a Working Time application exposed in Work Zone. When users access it, they see sub-applications such as:

  • Create Leave Request

  • Leave Overview

  • View Time Account Balances

When attempting to open any of these sub-applications, the following error occurs:

 

Configuration Overview

Build Work Zone Application Configuration

 

Run Destination Configuration 

Note: As mentioned earlier the content is not federated so Design Time destination not required in this case.

Additional Property of Destinaiton

 

Despite correct configuration on the Work Zone side, the issue persisted.

 

Analysis

After extensive analysis, we identified a relevant SAP Knowledge Base Article that describes the same issue:

SAP KBA 3385676
‚ÄúGetting Failed to resolve navigation target Shell-startWDA error in Work Zone‚Äù

This KBA pointed us in the right direction.

 

Resolution

As per the KBA, the fix needs to be applied on the S/4HANA side only.
No changes are required in SAP BTP Build Work Zone.

Steps to Resolve the Issue

  1. Open transaction SM30

  2. Enter the view name:

    /UI2/NWBC_CFGCV

  3. Add the following parameter:

    • Parameter Name: MAP_LEGACY_TO_IBN

    • Value: (leave it empty ‚Äî this disables the setting)

Before the Change

The view is empty, as shown below:

 

After the Change

The parameter is added with an empty value:

  1. Save the changes.

Result

After maintaining this parameter, the nested WDA applications were successfully accessible through SAP Build Work Zone without any navigation errors.

As per the above screen shot, the application is accessible. There is no HR data maintian for my id so the message is coming.

Conclusion

If you are facing navigation issues with nested WDA applications while migrating to SAP Build Work Zone, disabling IBN navigation for inner WDA navigation on the S/4HANA side can resolve the issue.

I hope this blog helps others save time during their migration journey.

 

Regards,
Rohit Gera

entry.title: Re: SAC Planning: Keep value unchanged when writing from...
entry.content:
Modifying your data action to include below steps might help to achieve the desired behaviour.

a) Copying the data from Measure A(Konditionswert (PLAN) Vorbelegung) to Measure B(Konditionswert (PLAN) by aggregating the data for dimension IBAN to '#' member

b) Using an Advanced Formula step to push the same value to each underlying account:

MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "KONDITIONSWERT_PLAN_VORBELEGUNG"
MEMBERSET [d/Kontosystem-ID] = "12345"

FOREACH [d/IBAN]
    DATA([d/Measures] = "KONDITIONSWERT_PLAN") =
        RESULTLOOKUP([d/IBAN] = "#")
ENDFOR

c) Delete the values copied in Step 1 to avoid double booking

MEMBERSET [d/Measures] = "KONDITIONSWERT_PLAN"
MEMBERSET [d/IBAN] = "#"
MEMBERSET [d/Kontosystem-ID] = "12345"

DATA() = 0

entry.title: Re: SAP SuccessFactors RCM Advanced Analytics
entry.content:
Hi, @bellashum91 !

The Hired and Not Qualified statuses not presenting themselves is expected behavior. Both Hired and Not Qualified are RMK statuses, therefore they cannot be mapped. They're mapped to themselves by default and this cannot be configured. They will also not show up in the list of mapped statuses on the Summarize tab, because they are not mapped.

See the section : Advanced Analytics Status Mapping Exceptions of the Recruiting implementation guide.

Note that incoming statuses will follow one of two paths, if the incoming status name matches an internal RMK status the record will be processed without any mapping required, on the other hand when a status does not match exactly it will be flagged as an unmapped status and would require a manual mapping to one of the standard RMK statuses.
For example, 'Hired' would be processed without interaction while 'Hire' or any other variation would require the manual mapping to be completed before the record is further processed.

entry.title: Email Notifications in Purchase Requisition Flexible Workflow
entry.content:
Email Notifications in Purchase Requisition Flexible Workflow

While processing the purchase requisition workflow, email notifications are triggered at different stages. Certain configurations are required to receive these email notifications. SAP provides standard templates for different stages that need to be copied to configure email notifications.

Email Notification to the Workflow Approver

When a purchase requisition is created, and the workflow is triggered then it will go to the approver based on the workflow configuration in the application "Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions‚Äù. During this process,

email notifications can be configured to be sent to the approver.

Prerequisites: The Flexible workflow for purchase requisition has already been configured.

Standard Email Template: SWF_CRT_NOTIFY_RECIPIENTS

Pattern for naming Convention: <YY1>_<SCENARIO_ID>_CRT_<ACTIVITY_NODEID> or <YY1>_< SCENARIO_ID>_CRT_ALL

Purchase Requisition workflow scenario and activity node id list:

Scenario Id

Activity Id

Description

WS02000458 (Overall release of regular purchase requisitions)

19

Release of Purchase Requisition

WS02000458 (Overall release of regular purchase requisitions)

29

Release of Reworkable Purchase Requisition  

WS02000458 (Overall release of regular purchase requisitions)

57

Review Workflow of Purchase Requisition

WS02000458 (Overall release of regular purchase requisitions)

42

Rework Purchase Requisition

WS02000471(item-level release of regular purchase requisitions)

20

Release of Purchase Requisition

WS02000471(item-level release of regular purchase requisitions)

31

Release of Reworkable Purchase Requisition  

WS02000471(item-level release of regular purchase requisitions)

56

Review Workflow of Purchase Requisition

WS02000471(item-level release of regular purchase requisitions)

45

Rework Purchase Requisition

WS02000434 (Overall release of central purchase requisitions)

20

Release of Purchase Requisition

WS02000434 (Overall release of central purchase requisitions)

41

Release of Reworkable Purchase Requisition  

WS02000434 (Overall release of central purchase requisitions)

69

Review Workflow of Purchase Requisition

WS02000434 (Overall release of central purchase requisitions)

56

Rework Purchase Requisition

WS02000438 (Item-level release of central purchase requisitions)

32

Release of Purchase Requisition

WS02000438 (Item- level release of central purchase requisitions)

51

Release of Reworkable Purchase Requisition  

WS02000438 (Item- level release of central purchase requisitions)

73

Review Workflow of Purchase Requisition

WS02000438 (Item- level release of central purchase requisitions)

63

Rework Purchase Requisition

 

Steps to be followed:

  1. Open standard email template in ‚ÄúMaintain email templates‚Äù application.

 

  1. Select standard email template and click on the Copy button to create custom email template.

 

Name of the Email Template should be given as per the pattern.

Example 1: If you want to create template for specific activity such as ‚ÄúRelease of Purchase Requisition‚Äù then in this case custom email template name will be YY1_02000458_CRT_19.

 

Example 2: If you want to create template for complete workflow scenario then in this case custom template name will be YY1_02000458_CRT_ALL.  

 

 

 

Email Notification after Workflow Approval or Rejection

When a purchase requisition workflow is approved or rejected by the workflow approver, you can configure email notifications to send emails to notify about the status.

There are two ways to configure email notification to be sent after approval or rejection.

  1. Using email template SWF_WORKFLOW_COMPLETE_NOTIFY: -Using this template, email will be triggered to purchase requisition creator on the approval/rejection.

         Prerequisites: The flexible workflow has already been configured.

         Steps to be followed: -

  1. Open standard email template SWF_WORKFLOW_COMPLETE_NOTIFY in ‚ÄúMaintain email templates‚Äù application. 

 

  1. Select standard email template and click on Copy button to create custom email template by given name as per the pattern:  

YY1_<SCENARIO_ID>_COMPLETE_POSITIVE - When workflow approved

YY1_<SCENARIO_ID>_COMPLETE_NEGATIVE - When workflow rejected.

 

Purchase Requisition workflow approved scenario: YY1_02000458_COMPLETE_POSITIVE

 

 

Purchase Requisition workflow rejection scenario: YY1_00800238_COMPLETE_NEGATIVE

 

 

 

 Notes:

  • If you use the email template SWF_WORKFLOW_COMPLETE_NOTIFY to send email after approval or rejection mentioned above, then email will always go to purchase requisition creator.
  • This is a generic way of configuring emails, so while creating a custom email template, the available data fields will not be specific to the purchase Requisition.
  1. Configure email notification in ‚ÄúManage workflows for purchase requisitions‚Äù application: - 

Using this approach, you will have option to maintain recipient to whom you wanted to send email notification after purchase Requisition workflow approval or rejection and while creating custom email template, available data fields will be more specific to purchase Requisition.

Below standard email templates will be used to create custom email template.

MMPUR_PRITM_WFL_APPROVE_EMAIL - Email Notification for Purchase Requisition Item Approval

MMPUR_PRITM_WFL_REJECT_EMAIL - Email Notification for Purchase Requisition Item Rejection

MMPUR_PRHDR_WFL_APPROVE_EMAIL - Email Notification for Purchase Requisition Header Approval

MMPUR_PRHDR_WFL_REJECT_EMAIL - Email Notification for Purchase Requisition Header Rejection

MMPUR_CPRITM_WFL_APPROVE_EMAIL - Email Notification for Central Purchase Requisition Item Approval

MMPUR_CPRITM_WFL_REJECT_EMAIL - Email Notification for Central Purchase Requisition Item Rejection

MMPUR_CPRHDR_WFL_APPROVE_EMAIL - Email Notification for Central Purchase Requisition Header Approval

MMPUR_CPRHDR_WFL_REJECT_EMAIL - Email Notification for Central Purchase Requisition Header Rejection

Steps to be followed for creating email templates: -

  1. Open standard email template in ‚ÄúMaintain email templates‚Äù application.

Example: header level approval of PR: MMPUR_PRHDR_WFL_APPROVE_EMAIL

 

  1. Select standard email template and click on the Copy button to create custom email. You can take any name for custom form template which does not exist.
  2. Naming Pattern: YY1_<any name>

For approval:

 

 

 

For rejection:

 

 

Deadline Email Notification:

The "Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions" Fiori application allows you to configure deadline monitoring and set up custom email notifications to keep approvers informed about pending approvals and new work items, ensuring timely approvals and efficient workflow management.

Copy the pre-delivered email template into the custom name space. The pre-delivered templates for the various workflow scenarios are as follows:

MMPUR_CPRHD_WF_DEADLINE_EMAIL - Email Notification for Central Purchase Requisition Deadline

MMPUR_CPRITM_WFL_DEADLINE_EMAIL - Email Notification for Central Purchase Requisition Item Deadline

MMPUR_PRHDR_WFL_DEADLINE_EMAIL - Email Notification for Purchase Requisition Header Deadline

MMPUR_PRITM_WFL_DEADLINE_EMAIL - Email Notification for Purchase Requisition Item Deadline

custom template must follow the following pattern: YY1_<Any Name>

For example: YY1_MyNotificationTemplate

 

 

Transport email template:

Open app ‚ÄúConfigure Software Package‚Äù, click Add Registration, and then select any package

 

 

Active ‚Äúautomatic task handling‚Äù

 

Create a workbench TR by using SE10

 

 

 

For TR to package by using ‚ÄúConfigure Software Package‚Äù

 

 

Assign Template to package by using app ‚ÄúRegister Extensions for transport‚Äù

Select Templates and reassign package.

 

 

For a different landscape (DEV to QA), release the transport request and import it into the target client.

Configure notification while creating workflow:

  1. Open ‚ÄúManage workflows for purchase Requisitions‚Äù application to create workflow. 
  2. To create workflow, click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button

 

 

 

  1. Go to the Notification tab and click on the create button.

 

  1. Fill in the required details and click on the create button.

Workflow Result: To enable notifications after approval or rejection, select the appropriate option from the dropdown menu.

E-Mail Template: For all the workflow result action, all the configured email template for the overall purchase Requisition approval and rejection will be displayed, which are created by copying pre-delivered email templates: -

MMPUR_PRHDR_WFL_APPROVE_EMAIL for approval

MMPUR_PRHDR_WFL_REJECT_EMAIL for Rejection

 

Please select proper email template for each action.

 

Recipients: Under recipients section you can maintain user to whom you want to send email notification after approval/rejection using fields Assignment By and Role.

For example, if you want to send email notification to workflow initiator then you can select value for ‚ÄúAssignment By‚Äù as ‚ÄúRole‚Äù and value for Role as ‚ÄúWorkflow initiator‚Äù.

Configured details for approval: Fill below details and Click on Create button. After clicking on Create button you will be able to see email notification configured under notification tab.

 

To configure email notification in same workflow for rejection email click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button again under notification tab.

 

Fill required details and click on ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button.

Email notification will show for both approval and rejection under ‚ÄúNotification‚Äù tab.

 

For more details, refer to How to Configure the Flexible Workflow for Purchase Requisitions

Start exploring with SAP Solution Scout and make smarter, faster decisions that drive efficiency and growth.

entry.title: Building an Email-Based SAP Sales Order Automation with n8n & AI Function Calling
entry.content:
Building an Email-Based SAP Sales Order Assistant with AI Function Calling

The Problem That Started This

A few weeks ago, I was watching a colleague struggle with a simple request: "Can you check if order 10850 shipped?" They had to VPN in, open SAP GUI, navigate to VA03, enter the order number, and finally get the answer. For one question. That took 3 minutes.

I thought - what if they could just send an email and get an answer back?

Why Not Just Use Rules or Keywords?

My first instinct was simple pattern matching. Look for "create order" then run the create flow. Look for "check status" then run the query flow. Easy, right?

Then I looked at actual emails people send:

  • "Hey, can you set up an order for 17100003? They need 5 of TG11 and 10 of TG12"
  • "pls make SO for cust 17100003 - TG11 x5, TG12 x10"
  • "Customer 17100003 wants to place an order. Materials: TG11 (5 units), TG12 (10 units)"

Same request, completely different wording. Building regex patterns for every variation? That's a maintenance nightmare waiting to happen. And what about typos, abbreviations, or when someone writes in a mix of languages?

This is exactly where AI shines - understanding intent regardless of how it's expressed.

Why Function Calling Instead of Free-Form AI?

I didn't want the AI making up SAP field names or guessing at API structures. That's a recipe for errors. Function calling gives you the best of both worlds:

  • The AI handles the messy, unpredictable part (understanding what the user wants)
  • The code handles the precise, structured part (calling SAP correctly)

You define exactly what functions exist and what parameters they accept. The AI picks the right function and extracts the right values. No hallucinated field names, no invented API calls.

The Architecture

Four components working together:

  1. Microsoft Outlook - Triggers when an email arrives
  2. LLM with Function Calling - Interprets the email, picks the operation
  3. n8n - Orchestrates everything, handles data transformation
  4. SAP S/4HANA OData APIs - Does the actual work

 

Setting Up n8n with Docker (The Network Gotchas)

I run n8n locally in Docker, and connecting it to an on-premise SAP system over VPN was... an adventure. Here's what I learned.

The Basic Setup

docker run -it --rm \
  --name n8n \
  -p 5678:5678 \
  --add-host=host.docker.internal:host-gateway \
  -v n8n_data:/home/node/.n8n \
  docker.n8n.io/n8nio/n8n

That --add-host=host.docker.internal:host-gateway flag is crucial. It lets containers reference your host machine's network. Without it, your container is isolated and can't see anything your host can see - including VPN connections.

The VPN Problem

Here's the thing: when you connect to a VPN on your Mac, the VPN routes are available to your host machine, but Docker containers live in their own network namespace. They can't directly reach 172.16.0.11:44300 even though your browser can.

You might think "just use --network host" - but on macOS, that doesn't work the way you'd expect. Docker Desktop on Mac runs containers in a Linux VM, so --network host gives you the VM's network, not your Mac's network.

The socat Bridge Solution

The workaround is to run a TCP forwarder on your host that bridges the connection:

socat TCP-LISTEN:15001,fork,reuseaddr TCP:172.16.0.11:44300

This listens on port 15001 on your Mac and forwards traffic to the SAP server at 172.16.0.11:44300. Now from inside Docker, you can reach SAP at:

https://host.docker.internal:15001/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_SALES_ORDER_SRV/A_SalesOrder

The flow is: Docker container ‚Üí host.docker.internal:15001 ‚Üí socat on your Mac ‚Üí VPN ‚Üí SAP server

Keep the socat command running in a terminal while you're working. Kill it when you're done.

Quick Tip: If you're getting "connection refused" errors, check that:

  1. Your VPN is connected
  2. socat is running
  3. You're using host.docker.internal, not localhost or the direct IP

The Functions I Defined

Three operations cover most daily requests:

get_sales_orders

"Show me recent orders," "What's the status of order X?"

Parameters: $top, $filter, $orderby

create_sales_order

"Create an order for customer X with these items"

Parameters: SoldToParty, items[] (Material, RequestedQuantity), plus optional fields

update_sales_order

"Change the PO reference on order 10904"

Parameters: SalesOrder (required), plus any fields to update

When an email comes in, the AI returns structured JSON:

{
  "function": "create_sales_order",
  "arguments": {
    "SoldToParty": "17100003",
    "items": [
      {"Material": "TG11", "RequestedQuantity": "5"},
      {"Material": "TG12", "RequestedQuantity": "10"}
    ]
  }
}

Clean, predictable, easy to work with.

The CSRF Token Headache

I have to mention this because it cost me hours. SAP OData APIs require CSRF tokens for write operations. Sounds simple - fetch a token, send it with your POST. But here's what the documentation doesn't make obvious:

The token is tied to your session cookies. You need to:

  1. GET request with x-csrf-token: fetch header
  2. Capture the token AND the SAP_SESSIONID cookie from the response
  3. Send BOTH with your write request

I kept getting "CSRF token validation failed" with a perfectly valid token. Turns out I was missing the session cookie. The token alone is useless without it.

Another gotcha in n8n

The cookie header comes back with extra metadata like path=/; secure; HttpOnly. If you pass that whole string in your Cookie header, you'll get "Invalid character in header content." You need to extract just the cookie value:

// In an Edit Fields node, clean the cookie
$json.headers['set-cookie'][0].split(';')[0] + '; ' + 
$json.headers['set-cookie'][1].split(';')[0]

This gives you a clean sap-usercontext=sap-client=100; SAP_SESSIONID_S4H_100=abc123... that SAP will accept.

 

Data Transformation for Deep Insert

One more SAP quirk: when creating an order with line items, you can't just send an items array. SAP expects a nested structure called to_Item.results. In n8n's Code node:

const args = JSON.parse(
  $input.first().json.choices[0].message.tool_calls[0].function.arguments
);
const body = { ...args };

if (body.items) {
  body.to_Item = { results: body.items };
  delete body.items;
}

return [{ json: { sapBody: body } }];

This transforms the AI's clean output into SAP's expected format.

 

A Real Example

Input Email

Hello, please create a sales order with the following details:
Customer: 17100003
Sales Org: 1710
Items: TG11 (qty 5), TG12 (qty 10)
Currency: USD

What Happens

  1. AI identifies this as create_sales_order
  2. Extracts: customer, items array, currency
  3. Workflow fetches CSRF token + session cookie
  4. Transforms items array to SAP's to_Item.results format
  5. POSTs to /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_SALES_ORDER_SRV/A_SalesOrder
  6. SAP creates order, returns details

Response Email

The user never touched SAP. They just sent an email.

What's Next

The same pattern works for anything with an OData API:

  • Invoice queries
  • Delivery status checks
  • Material lookups
  • Customer master updates

Define the function, connect the endpoint, done.

The Takeaway

AI isn't replacing SAP knowledge here - it's translating between human language and system requirements. The business logic, the validations, the actual processing - that's all still SAP. The AI just makes it accessible to people who don't speak SAP.

And honestly? That's the kind of AI use case I find most valuable. Not replacing expertise, but removing friction.

entry.title: The Integration of SAP Business Data Cloud and Customer Data Platform Multiplies the Value
entry.content:
In every industry, data lives in many places: applications, data lakes, warehouses, and partner ecosystems. The challenge isn‚Äôt just collecting it; it‚Äôs understanding, governing, and activating it in business context without endless copying and re-engineering.  SAP Business Data Cloud  addresses this challenge by giving you a governed, business-ready data foundation that connects SAP and non-SAP sources, preserves business meaning, and makes data easy to use across analytics and AI. 

When you publish curated, consent-aware data products from SAP Business Data Cloud to SAP Customer Data Platform (CDP), you turn that foundation into real-time engagement, personalization, and growth, while preserving governance and trust

 

 

 

 

 

 

What SAP Business Data Cloud does 

Business Data Cloud unifies access to SAP and non-SAP data and lets you model it with business semantics (master data, measures, relationships). It brings centralized governance (catalog, lineage, policies, masking) and a federated data fabric to minimize unnecessary copies. The result is an analytics- and AI-ready layer you can operationalize via APIs, events, and lifecycle controls at enterprise scale.

What SAP Customer Data Platform does 

CDP ingests batch and streaming data from web/mobile, commerce, CRM, service, and adtech/martech. It resolves identities into unified person or account profiles, models profiles and events with relationships, and enforces consent and purpose-based policies. Teams build segments using attributes and behaviors, activate them to channels in batch or near real time, and govern usage with roles, lineage, and monitoring. CDP also exposes APIs and supports importing predictive scores to enrich engagement.

Why Publish SAP Business Data Cloud data to SAP Customer Data Platform

  • Richer, governed context: Share curated customer, order, product, and service attributes so CDP segments reflect true business semantics (for example, lifecycle stage, CLV).
  • Consistent, compliant activation: Carry consent and standardized definitions (VIP, churn risk, eligibility) into every channel to reduce drift and ensure compliant use.
  • Faster time to value: Publish ready-to-use data products so marketing, sales, and service can build segments and journeys without re-engineering upstream data.

How it works in practice (Business Data Cloud ‚Üí CDP)

  • Prepare governed data products in Business Data Cloud, tagging PII, consent, and purpose metadata.
  • Deliver via secure connectors, APIs, or scheduled exports; use incremental updates or events for freshness.
  • Configure CDP ingestion and identity rules, map schemas, and apply data minimization on ingest.
  • Build segments, activate to destinations, and where supported, feed engagement outcomes back to Business Data Cloud for continuous improvement.

Example use cases

  • Hyper-personalized campaigns: Target offers using eligibility rules and product hierarchies; CDP activates across channels while honoring consent.
  • Churn prevention: Publish churn scores and service history; CDP triggers save-offers and captures outcomes for model tuning.
  • B2B account-based engagement: Share account intent and entitlements; CDP unifies contacts-to-account, segments by buying center, and coordinates outreach.

More info

Suggested learning.sap.com resources and what to look for:

  • Exploring SAP Customer Data Platform Essentials 
  • Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud 

Official product documentation

  • Administering SAP Business Data Cloud
  • SAP Customer Data Platform Integration Guide

entry.title: How to call AS ABAP from SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
Introduction

For communication between SAP systems based on AS ABAP, RFC connections are the standard method. For example, when extracting from SAP ERP, the SAP BW system first launches the extractor in the source system via a BW->ERP RFC connection. The source system then returns the data collected by the extractor via an ERP->BW RFC connection.

For SAP Datasphere (hereinafter referred to as DSP), the natural successor to this approach is the BW Bridge use. However, not all projects justify using BW Bridge in terms of system landscape, architecture, project scope, and implementation costs.

This blog proposes an approach that allows DSP to execute code in a system running AS ABAP (without using BW Bridge). We will call this code as target code. The idea is to leverage CDS functionality known such as Virtual Elements. A Virtual Element is a field in a CDS View Entity, specifically defined using annotations. This field is not retrieved from the database table level and is not calculated by formulas within the CDS View itself. Instead, accessing the CDS View triggers execution of specialized ABAP code that implements the calculation logic for this field. For BW specialists this may remember well-known virtual characteristics and key figures. On the other hand, the CDS View is an object accessible to DSPs, for example, as a Source for Data Flow. Thus, by running Data Flow Run on the DSP side, we automatically initiate execution of the code that calculates the Virtual Element values ‚Äã‚Äãin AS ABAP. We can, in turn, include calls of any desired programs, functional modules, or class methods to this code‚Äîthat is, achieve the execution of the target code.

Unfortunately, this approach has one significant drawback that complicates its implementation: Virtual elements are only function within OData services generated from CDS views. This means that we cannot use connections of type SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP ABAP, or SAP BW on the DSP side. You will need to create a Generic OData connection.

Implementation plan is following:

  1. Create a CDS View Entity in S/4HANA using a Virtual Element.
  2. Create an ABAP class that implements the calculation of this Virtual Element. The class code will include the target code call.
  3. Register and test the OData Service.
  4. Review the permissions required for the technical user on whose behalf the connection will be made. These permissions should be broader than the standard permissions for connections of type SAP S/4HANA On-Premise or SAP ABAP.
  5. Notes regarding creating a Generic OData connection in DSP.
  6. Create a simple Data Flow in DSP using the OData connection to the created CDS View. Running this Data Flow (manually, scheduled, or as part of a Task Chain) will trigger our target code in S/4HANA.

CDS View Entity with Virtual Element

We will create a dummy CDS View. It doesn't need to provide any meaningful data. We only need the ability to add a Virtual Element field to it. Therefore, as an example, we'll use a selection from the TKA01 (Controlling Areas) table. Typically, a single Controlling Area with a value of 1000 is used. Based on this assumption, we'll create the CDS View. Of course, you can use other selections that are guaranteed to return a single record in your system. The following code is proposed:

@EndUserText.label: 'CDS Virtual Element Test'
@analytics.dataCategory: #DIMENSION
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@vdm.viewType: #BASIC
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations:true
@ObjectModel.usageType.serviceQuality: #A
@ObjectModel.usageType.sizeCategory: #S
@ObjectModel.usageType.dataClass: #MASTER
@analytics.dataExtraction.enabled: true
@analytics.dataExtraction.delta.changeDataCapture.automatic: true
@ObjectModel.supportedCapabilities:[#EXTRACTION_DATA_SOURCE]
@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@odata.publish: true

define view entity Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM as select from tka01
{
key kokrs,
substring( cast( tstmp_current_utctimestamp() as abap.char(17) ), 1, 8 ) as dat,
@ObjectModel.readOnly: true
@ObjectModel.virtualElement: true
@ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP:ZCL_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CALC'
cast('' as abap.sstring( 1 )) as flag
}
where kokrs = '1000'
  •  The annotation at line 13 enables access to the CDS View via the OData Service.
  • The ‚Äòdat‚Äô field is added as a simple log: to see the date of the last calculation run.
  • The ‚Äòflag‚Äô field of the Virtual Element type is defined at line 22. It has the simplest form of a flag field. By default, as can be seen from the code, this field is empty. However, upon completion of calculations on the AS ABAP side, it will be filled with the value 'X'. This flag confirms at DSP side the successful completion of ABAP calculations.
  • The annotations at lines 19-21 define the "flag" field as a Virtual Element. In particular, the @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy annotation specifies the name of the ABAP class that should calculate the ‚Äòflag‚Äô field.

When you initially activate this code, you'll receive, in particular, two warnings. For line 13 the system reports that the corresponding OData service is not active. For line 21 the system reports that the corresponding class doesn't exist. In the next steps, we'll resolve these issues.

If we use the context menu command 'Open With -> Data Preview' on our CDS View at this point, the result will be as follows:Here the 'kokrs' and 'dat' fields are populated using standard CDS syntax. The virtual 'flag' field is left blank.

Creation of ABAP Class implementing our calculations

A Virtual Element calculation implementing  class must use two standard interfaces: IF_SADL_EXIT –∏ IF_SADL_EXIT_CALC_ELEMENT_READ:

class ZCL_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CALC definition
public
final
create public .

public section.

interfaces IF_SADL_EXIT .
interfaces IF_SADL_EXIT_CALC_ELEMENT_READ .
protected section.
private section.
ENDCLASS.

Second of these interfaces has two standard methods. A detailed description of these methods and their parameters can be found in the official documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_BW4HANA/cc0c305d2fab47bd808adcad3ca7ee9d/4b5e56ec6f28453f81a...

In our example, the following code is proposed for the GET_CALCULATION_INFO method:

METHOD if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read~get_calculation_info.
IF iv_entity = 'Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM'.
"Here we'll list which fields of CDS View will be used in virtual element calculation
IF line_exists( it_requested_calc_elements[ table_line = 'FLAG' ] ).
APPEND 'KOKRS' TO et_requested_orig_elements.
ENDIF.
ELSE.
" Potential errors should be processed by public constants,
" described in exceptional class, inherited from CX_SADL_EXIT.
" For example, if CDS View is unknown:

RAISE EXCEPTION TYPE zcx_ds_virt_elem_exceptions EXPORTING textid = zcx_ds_virt_elem_exceptions=>c_entity_not_known.
ENDIF.
ENDMETHOD.

Errors occurring during execution of the class described above must be handled using system messages. For this purpose, public constants will be created in a separate exception class. The class must be a child of the standard CX_SADL_EXIT class. An example of such an exception class is provided in the official documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_NETWEAVER_AS_ABAP_751_IP/cc0c305d2fab47bd808adcad3ca7ee9d/8cf451799476...  

As we can see, after specifying the parent class, a small constructor override is required. Each error is then declared as a public constant attribute. Naturally, such attribute contains a system message, previously defined in the Message Class relevant to the task.

Since our CDS View is designed to be as simple as possible, the IT_REQUESTED_CALC_ELEMENTS table will contain a single row with the ‚ÄòFLAG‚Äô field. The ET_REQUESTED_ORIG_ELEMENTS table of regular source fields also contains only one record with the ‚ÄòKOKRS‚Äô field.

Let's move on to the CALCULATE method:

METHOD if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read~calculate.
CHECK NOT it_original_data IS INITIAL.
DATA lit_calculated_data TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF z_cds_virt_elem WITH DEFAULT KEY.
MOVE-CORRESPONDING it_original_data TO lit_calculated_data.

LOOP AT lit_calculated_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_calculated_data>).
"Here we need to add a call to the code that we wanted to initiate from the DSP side.
"For example, we can submit some program:
" SUBMIT z_some_program AND RETURN.
<lfs_calculated_data>-flag = 'X'. "Formal flag of the calculation readiness
EXIT. "Additional guarantee that calculation will be performed only once
ENDLOOP.
MOVE-CORRESPONDING lit_calculated_data TO ct_calculated_data.
ENDMETHOD.

Our CDS View is intentionally designed to return exactly one record. This means that in the CALCULATE method, the IT_ORIGINAL_DATA table also contains exactly one record. Consequently, the LOOP/ENDLOOP loop will only be executed once, and the target code will also be called only once.

After the ZCL_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CALC class is activated, the warning on line 21 of our CDS View code will disappear.

OData Service activation

Our CDS View annotation specifies that it can be accessed via an OData Service. When we activate the CDS code, the corresponding OData Service will be created but not activated. Activation must be performed manually in the /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE transaction. The OData Service name consists of the name of our CDS View followed by the _CDS suffix. In our example, the resulting name is Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS.

Click the 'Add Service' button:

 An ‚ÄòAdd Selected Services‚Äô window will appear. Enter Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS as the technical name, and select LOCAL from the list in the 'System Alias' field. Then click 'Get Services'. A line with our service should appear:

 Select the row with service description and press the ‚ÄòAdd Selected Services‚Äô button:In the 'Package Assignment' field, specify the appropriate package for subsequent import of developed objects to the production system. In the 'ICF Node' section, select the 'SAP Gateway OData V2' setting. An important setting is the 'Enable OAuth for Service' checkbox. Check with your BASIS Team to determine whether OAuth will be used when connecting the DSP to the ABAP system. If so, enable this checkbox. After confirming the settings, service activation will begin. Upon completion, the following message will appear: 

Now you need to return to the main transaction window and filter the newly activated service in the list:

 Check the traffic light in the 'Status' field (the leftmost field in the ICF Nodes section). If it's yellow, select the drop-down list from the 'ICF Node' button directly above it and execute the 'Activate' command:

The window for selecting a package for importing activated objects into production will appear again:

After this, the traffic light will change to green. You can now test the service by clicking the 'SAP Gateway Client' button:

 By default, the test transaction specifies a URI that reads the service description:

But we're interested in what entities this service can provide. This can be found by clicking the 'Entity Set' button:

Here we see that the service can read data for CDS View Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM. By double-clicking this name, we can change the URI:

If you now click the 'Execute' button, data will be read from the CDS View Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM via the OData Service. This is precisely the operation that should trigger the calculation of the 'flag' field via the ABAP class described above. If you need to study or debug this class, you can set breakpoints there before clicking 'Execute'. The calculation results will be presented here in XML format:Here you can see that the 'flag' field is filled with the value 'X'. This means that the CALCULATE method was executed along with the target code call.

System user authorizations

When creating a DSP connection to an ABAP system, a special user of the System type is used. Typically, the BASIS Team assigns this user a standard set of permissions sufficient for connections of SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP ABAP, or SAP BW types. Experience has shown that a Generic OData connection requires a number of additional permissions.

First, you need to add authorizations to launch the created OData Service. This is the S_SERVICE authorization object. Editing it differs from most standard authorization objects. After adding the object to the role profile, click the edit button for the SRV_NAME field. In the window that appears, select 'TADIR Service' from the Type drop-down list, which will display a list of services allowed to launch:

We need to add two types of objects for our service: IWSG and IWSV. First, select the appropriate type from the list in the 'Object Type' column. Then, use the search (for example, by pressing F4) in the 'Object Name' column. In both cases, you can use the name of our service (i.e. -  Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS) to search for the desired value:The name of the object being searched consists of the service name and the ordinal number of the active version of this service (four digits). For the first version of service in our example, the IWSG type value is 'Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS_0001', and the IWSV type value is 'Z_CDS_VIRT_ELEM_CDS 0001'.

After saving the selected values, you will see that the value 'HT' is automatically added to the SRV_TYPE field. Thus, the S_SERVICE authorizations have been added and the values ‚Äã‚Äãspecified.

It is also important to note that specific authorizations may be required, which depend on the specific target code you want to run in the CALCULATE method described above. For example, if you plan to use a command like 'SUBMIT z_some_program AND RETURN' to launch a program, you will need the corresponding authorizations in the S_PROGRAM object. If the target code performs, for example, calculations related to the FI module, the system user may require authorizations specific to that module. If the target code accesses the contents of database tables, authorizations in the S_TABU_DIS and S_TABU_NAM objects may be required. And so on. Most likely, during the OData service testing phase (as described in the previous section), you will need to collaborate with the BASIS Team to monitor missing authorizations and add them to the system user's roles. The simplest solution is to temporarily (and only in the development system!) change the user type from system to dialog. In this case, you can log in to the SAP GUI with this user's login and manually run OData service testing while simultaneously monitoring the authorizations being checked.

The security issue of assigning such non-typical authorizations to a system user is mitigated by the fact that this user is created only to connect DSP to the ABAP system and cannot be used for manual data access, like a dialog user.

DSP OData Connection

Creating a Generic OData connection should be performed by BASIS Team specialists, as the required settings depend on the system landscape used in your specific project, as well as the security settings applied (for example, whether OAuth is enabled). Here's an example of the settings used in our project:The address entered in the ‚ÄòURL‚Äô field ends with the technical name of our OData service. Therefore, a separate connection will need to be created for each OData service.

In the ‚ÄòVersion‚Äô field, V2 is selected. This is because we specified OData V2 when activating the service above and didn't have the option to select V4:

The example also shows that OAuth is used. That's why the corresponding checkbox was enabled earlier when activating the service:

At the bottom of the connection settings window, click the ‚ÄòShow Advanced Properties‚Äô button:

Here you need to specify for the OData service the client number of the ABAP system we are connecting to:

 

DSP Data Flow to use OData connection and trigger the target code

We need to create a Data Flow with our OData service as a source. To do this, open Data Builder (in the same Space where you created OData service connection). In the left pane, select the 'Sources' tab and open the 'Connections' folder:

If all connection settings and system user authorizations were configured correctly, you will see the connection, and when you expand it, you will see the name of our CDS View:

The icon next to the CDS View is the same as for a regular table. You can drag and drop this View into the Data Flow being created. It will be automatically recognized as a Source. At this step, you can select the 'Preview Data' command for this table:

The result should look like this:

The presence of an 'X' in the 'flag' field means that the target code has been executed on the ABAP system side. If the target code execution takes a long time, you will also notice the delay when viewing it in the DSP.

As a final step, you need to complete the Data Flow by adding the target table to it, which in this case only serves as a dummy. Save the Data Flow and deploy it.

Result

Now you can initiate execution of the target code in the ABAP system in any way convenient for you: by manually starting the Data Flow, scheduling it, or including the Data Flow in a Task Chain.

 

 

Note: Data Preview is not working for Virtual Element

As a result of our implementation, OData Service is activated and implementing ABAP class exist for our Virtual Element. And  we can repeat attempt of CDS data preview in ABAP Development Tools (CDS editor context menu command 'Open With -> Data Preview'). Unfortunately, result will be the same: field ‚Äòflag‚Äô is empty: 

This is explained by the fact that the Virtual Element calculation is performed only when accessing the CDS through OData Service.

entry.title: Re: Adobe forms: Header paragraph need to repeat every page
entry.content:
Hello,

If you want heading tables on every page why don't you put it on master page? if you put it on master page it will appear every page then.

entry.content:
Hi CAPer's ,

 

Any one facing the issue with login to BTP trial account?

Interestingly, the problem sometimes resolves itself after several attempts. Is there a solution available for this issue?

„Ç≠„Éº„Éé„Éº„Éà„Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„Å´Á∂ö„ÅèÂêÑÊ©üËÉΩ„ÅÆÂÄãÂà•„Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„Åß„ÅØ„ÄÅSAP Cloud ALM„ÅÆÂ∞éÂÖ•ÔºèÈÅãÁî®Ê©üËÉΩ„ÅÆ„ÅîÁ¥π‰ªã„Å†„Åë„Åß„ÅØ„Å™„Åè„ÄÅSAP Solution Manager„Åã„Çâ„ÅÆÁßªË°å„ÄÅÁµ±Âêà„ÉÑ„Éº„É´„ÉÅ„Çß„Éº„É≥„ÅÆÂêÑ„ÉÑ„Éº„É´„Å´„Åä„Åë„ÇãAIÊ¥ªÁî®„ÅÆÂÆüÊÉÖ„ÄÅ„Åæ„ÅüBusiness Transformation Center„ÇÑ„Çª„Ç≠„É•„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£ÂàÜÊûê„Å®„ÅÑ„Å£„ÅüÊØîËºÉÁöÑÊñ∞„Åó„ÅÑ„Éà„Éî„ÉÉ„ÇØ„ÇÇ„Ç¢„Ç∏„Çß„É≥„ÉÄ„Å´ÁµÑ„ÅøËæº„Åø„ÄÅÂêÑÈ†òÂüü„ÅÆ„Ç®„Ç≠„Çπ„Éë„Éº„Éà„Åã„Çâ„ÅîË™¨Êòé„Åï„Åõ„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åü„Å†„Åç„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ

„Åæ„Åü„ÄÅ‰ªäÂõûÊó•Êú¨ÈõªÊ∞óÊßò„Å´„ÅîÁôªÂ£á„ÅÑ„Åü„Å†„Åç„ÄÅÁèæÂú®ÈÄ≤„ÇÅ„Å¶„Åä„Çâ„Çå„ÇãÁµ±Âêà„ÉÑ„Éº„É´„ÉÅ„Çß„Éº„É≥„ÅÆÂèñ„ÇäÁµÑ„Åø„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÅîË™¨Êòé„ÅÑ„Åü„Å†„ÅÑ„Åü„Åì„Å®„ÅåÁâπÁ≠Ü„Åô„Åπ„ÅçÁÇπ„Å®„Åó„Å¶Êåô„Åí„Çâ„Çå„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÂÆüÈöõ„ÅÆ„ÅîÁµåÈ®ì„Åã„ÇâÂæó„Çâ„Çå„ÇãÂ§ßÂ§âË≤¥Èáç„Å™ÊÉÖÂ†±„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ„Åì„Å®„ÇÇ„ÅÇ„Çä„ÄÅ„Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥ÂΩìÊó•„ÅØ„ÅîÂèÇÂä†„ÅÑ„Åü„Å†„ÅÑ„ÅüÊñπ„ÄÖ„Åã„ÇâÊôÇÈñì„ÇÆ„É™„ÇÆ„É™„Åæ„ÅßÊï∞Â§ö„Åè„ÅÆ„ÅîË≥™Âïè„ÅåÂá∫„Å¶„Åä„Çä„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ

„Åì„Å°„Çâ„Åå‰ªäÂõûÊèê‰æõ„Åó„ÅüÂêÑ„Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÅÆË≥áÊñô„Å∏„ÅÆ„É™„É≥„ÇØ„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

„Äê1Êó•ÁõÆ„Äë

  • „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥1ÔºöKeynote 1 ‚Äì Èù©Êñ∞ÁöÑ„Å™Ê•≠ÂãôÊîπÈù©ÂÆüÁèæ„ÅÆÊâãÊÆµ„Å®„ÄÅ„Åù„Çå„ÇíÂÆüÁèæ„Åô„ÇãSAPÊà¶Áï•
  • „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥2ÔºöKeynote 2 ‚Äì Èù©Êñ∞ÁöÑ„Å™Ê•≠ÂãôÊîπÈù©ÂÆüÁèæ„ÅÆÊâãÊÆµ„Å®„ÄÅ„Åù„Çå„ÇíÂÆüÁèæ„Åô„ÇãSAPÊà¶Áï•
  • „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥3ÔºöSAP Solution Manager„É¶„Éº„Ç∂„Éº„ÇíÂæåÊäº„ÅóÔºÅSAP Cloud ALM„Å∏„ÅÆÁßªË°å„Å´Âêë„Åë„ÅüÊäº„Åï„Åà„Çã„Åπ„Åç„Éù„Ç§„É≥„Éà
  • „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥4ÔºöAI„ÇíÁî®„ÅÑ„ÅüÁµ±Âêà„ÉÑ„Éº„É´„ÉÅ„Çß„Éº„É≥„Å´„Çà„ÇãÈù©Êñ∞ÁöÑ„Å™„Éó„É≠„Ç∏„Çß„ÇØ„ÉàÁÆ°ÁêÜ

„Äê2Êó•ÁõÆ„Äë

  • „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥1ÔºöSAP Cloud ALM„ÅåÂÆüÁèæ„Åô„Çã„Çª„É≥„Éà„É©„É´„Ç™„Éñ„Ç∂„Éº„Éê„Éì„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£„Åä„Çà„Å≥„Ç∑„Çπ„ÉÜ„É†ÈÅãÁî®ÂäπÁéáÂåñ„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶
  • „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥2ÔºöSAP Cloud ALM„Çí‰Ωø„Å£„Åü„Çª„Ç≠„É•„É™„ÉÜ„Ç£ÂàÜÊûê„Åß‰Ωï„Åå„Åß„Åç„Çã„ÅÆ„Åã
  • „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥3ÔºöSAP„ÅåÊèê‰æõ„Åô„ÇãÊñ∞„Åü„Å™ÈÅ∏ÊäûËÇ¢„Éá„Éº„ÇøÁßªË°åÂêë„Åë„ÇΩ„É™„É•„Éº„Ç∑„Éß„É≥Business Transformation CenterÔºöSAP Cloud ALM
  • „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥4ÔºöSAP Cloud ALM„Å®Tricentis„ÅßÂÆüÁèæ„Åô„Çã„ÉÜ„Çπ„ÉàÂäπÁéáÂåñ„ÅÆÁèæÁä∂„Å®Â∞ÜÊù•ÂÉè

„Å™„Åä„ÄÅÂêÑ„Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÅÆ„É¨„Ç≥„Éº„Éá„Ç£„É≥„Ç∞„ÇíSAP„Ç∏„É£„Éë„É≥ÂÖ¨Âºè„ÅÆYoutube„ÉÅ„É£„É≥„Éç„É´Ôºàwww.youtube.com/@SAPJAPANÔºâ„Å´„Å¶‰ªäÂæåÈÖç‰ø°„Åô„Çã‰∫àÂÆö„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ„Åì„Å°„Çâ„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÅØ„ÄÅ„ÇÇ„ÅÜÊö´„Åè„ÅäÂæÖ„Å°„Åè„Å†„Åï„ÅÑ„ÄÇ

„Åæ„Åü„ÄÅSAP ALM Summit Japan 2024„Å´Âºï„ÅçÁ∂ö„Åç„ÄÅ‰ªäÂõû„ÇÇSolution Transformation Consultant training„ÇíÈñãÂÇ¨„ÅÑ„Åü„Åó„Åæ„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ

entry.title: SAP ALM Summit Japan 2025 event report
entry.content:
SAP ALM Summit Japan 2025 was held over two days, December 8 (Mon) and December 9 (Tue) last year, on the 11th floor of the SAP Japan Otemachi office.

This SAP ALM Summit is one of SAP‚Äôs global events, held annually in regions such as EMEA, North America, and Asia Pacific, and likewise in Japan toward the end of each year. We are very grateful that the number of participants has steadily increased every year, this time, approximately 100 customers and partners joined us over the two days. We would like to take this opportunity to express our sincere appreciation. Thank you very much.



In the opening keynote session, SAP‚Äôs Global Head of Support and Integrated Tool Chain shared the latest updates on SAP‚Äôs ALM strategy. Additionally, the Go‚Äëto‚ÄëMarket Lead for ALM introduced the current positioning of SAP Cloud ALM within the integrated tool chain and demonstrated AI‚Äëpowered features planned for future releases.
 

In the individual sessions that followed the keynote, experts from each area presented not only SAP Cloud ALM‚Äôs implementation and operations capabilities, but also topics such as migration from SAP Solution Manager, practical examples of AI utilization across tools in the integrated toolchain, Business Transformation Center, and security analytics‚Äîrelatively new themes that were newly added to this year‚Äôs agenda.

Another highlight was the session delivered by NEC Corporation, in which they shared their ongoing initiatives related to the integrated toolchain. Since their session was based on real‚Äëworld project experience, participants actively asked numerous questions until the very last minute.

Below are the links to the materials provided for each session:

Day1

  • Session 1ÔºöKeynote 1 ‚Äì Means for Achieving Innovative Business Transformation and SAP‚Äôs Strategy to Realize It
  • Session 2ÔºöKeynote 2 ‚Äì Means for Achieving Innovative Business Transformation and SAP‚Äôs Strategy to Realize It
  • Session 3ÔºöSupporting SAP Solution Manager Users! Key Points for Migrating to SAP Cloud ALM
  • Session 4ÔºöInnovative Project Management Enabled by an AI‚ÄëDriven Integrated Toolchain

Day2

  • Session 1ÔºöCentral Observability and Operational Efficiency Enabled by SAP Cloud ALM
  • Session 2ÔºöWhat Is Possible with Security Analytics Using SAP Cloud ALM
  • Session 3ÔºöBusiness Transformation Center for SAP Cloud ALM: A New SAP‚ÄëProvided Data Migration Solution
  • Session 4ÔºöCurrent State and Future Outlook of Test Optimization Using SAP Cloud ALM and Tricentis
The session recordings will be made available on the official SAP Japan YouTube channel (www.youtube.com/@SAPJAPAN) at a later date. Please stay tuned.
 
Following the SAP ALM Summit Japan 2024, we also held the Solution Transformation Consultant Training this year.
 

This training is designed to help participants understand and learn how to use various functions that support S/4HANA implementation projects and post‚Äëgo‚Äëlive operational optimization, based on the RISE with SAP Methodology and the clean core concept. A certification exam is provided to assess understanding, and those who pass receive a digital badge issued via Credly.

This time, hands‚Äëon workshops were conducted after the individual sessions on both Day 1 (Implementation track) and Day 2 (Operations track), followed by the certification exam.
Despite the very tight schedule, many customers and partners joined the program. We sincerely appreciate your participation.

This concludes our brief report on SAP ALM Summit Japan 2025.
The schedules for the 2026 ALM Summits in North America, Asia Pacific, and EMEA have already been announced (see details here).

As for the event in Japan, we will inform you once further details are finalized.

Thank you very much for reading.

entry.title: Re: Standard Webdynpro FPM - How to control variant manag...
entry.content:
Hi Collegue,

if you would like to control the availability of Public View Sharing, then please go through the following:

  • SAP Note https://me.sap.com/notes/3112220/E
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
    • Business Catalog SAP_CORE_BC_UI_SHARE_PC must be assigned to the business user via Maintain Business User app
  • SAP S/4HANA onPrem / Cloud Private Edition
    • SAP Note https://me.sap.com/notes/3040037/E
    • Catalog SAP_BC_WD_ADAPT_VIEW_SHARING

Best regards,

Simon

entry.title: Unlocking Reliability at Scale: Join Our Webinar on Asset Performance Management and Industry X
entry.content:
In the ever-evolving landscape of asset management, the integration of cutting-edge technology and innovative strategies is crucial for staying ahead. Here at SAP, in collaboration with Accenture, we are thrilled to invite you to a groundbreaking webinar designed to explore how Asset Performance Management (APM) and Industry X are revolutionizing the industry. This session will empower asset owners, plant managers, and reliability engineers to optimize maintenance strategies, enhance asset performance, and achieve sustainability objectives‚Äîall while tackling the most significant challenges facing the industry today.

Why Attend? This exclusive webinar provides a unique opportunity to:

- Gain Insight from Industry Leaders: Hear directly from M. Dias Branco about their transformative journey in asset management.
- Engage with Experts: Connect with international specialists from SAP and Accenture, and deepen your understanding of emerging trends and tools.
- Discover Next-Level Innovation: Learn how innovation and AI capabilities are unlocking new avenues of value within APM.
- Shape the Future: Participate in an interactive virtual workshop where your feedback can influence the direction of future advancements.

Agenda Highlights:

1. Introduction:
- Kick-off by highlighting the importance of integrating APM strategies with Industry X principles.

2. Trends in Asset Management and Industry X:
- Presented by John Holmes and Andy Hancock, this segment will delve into the current trends and why APM is more critical than ever.

3. M. Dias Branco Client Story:
- F√°bio Belemer will share insights from M. Dias Branco's experiences, illustrating the tangible benefits and successes from their journey.

4. Reliability-at-Scale Key Innovation for SAP Asset Performance Management:
- Elmar Paul will introduce the latest and planned innovations delivering reliability at scale, providing attendees with actionable strategies to implement in their operations.

5. Q&A Session:
- An open forum to discuss pressing questions and explore further the topics covered during the webinar.

Join us for this engaging session to catalyse your approach to asset management, foster sustainability, and lead in your industry with enhanced reliability and efficiency. Secure your spot in this transformative event and be part of shaping the future of Asset Performance Management.

Event Details:

- Date: February 03, 2026
- Time: 15:00, Central European Time
- Registration: https://event.on24.com/wcc/r/5199345/E56B1D05FCF1B34294C24833A52C0E2C

SAP Asset Performance Management

entry.title: Re: Show last 6 month data using fiscal period
entry.content:
TYPES : BEGIN OF ts_period ,

period TYPE numc3, ind type i,

END OF ts_period.



DATA : periodary TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ts_period.
periodary = VALUE #( ( period = '001' ind = 989 ) ( period = '002' ind = 1 ) ( period = '003' ind = 1 ) ( period = '004' ind = 1 )
( period = '005' ind = 1 ) ( period = '006' ind = 1 ) ( period = '007' ind = 1 ) ( period = '008' ind = 1 )
( period = '009' ind = 1 ) ( period = '010' ind = 1 ) ( period = '011' ind = 1 ) ( period = '012' ind = 1 ) ).

READ TABLE it_filter-TT_Fiscalyearperiod INTO DATA(ls_per) INDEX 1. " first period for example 2026001
DATA(lv_last) = substring( val = ls_per-low off = 4 len = 3 ).
data(ls_period) = periodary[ period = lv_last ] .
DATA(lv_ind) = ls_period-ind .
do 5 times.
ls_per-low = ls_per-low - lv_ind . "substring( val = ls_per-low off = 0 len = 4 ) && periodary[ ind = lv_ind ]-period.
append ls_per to it_filter-TT_Fiscalyearperiod.
lv_last = substring( val = ls_per-low off = 4 len = 3 ).
ls_period = periodary[ period = lv_last ] .
lv_ind = ls_period-ind.

ENDDO.

entry.title: Re: How to Disable Message Panel in Create Purchase Order (Advanced)
entry.content:
Hi,

The panel on the left is the Message Log / Information panel.
In Create Purchase Order (Advanced), SAP treats it as context-critical, so the app reopens it every time the app is launched.

Refer to KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/2971411 to disable it.

Thanks,

Krithika

entry.title: Re: Maintaining average inspection duration or GRPT based...
entry.content:
Hello @RaghavanKathamuthu 

I don't think you make Average Inspection Duration dependent on production version. However you can adjust QM inspection lot dates with the user-exit EXIT_SAPLQPL1_002. The exit has been migrated to BADI_QPL1_CHANGE_AT_CREATE.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski
